pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:0.5: 39. The training rule on fine foods
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.2: At that time the monks from the group of six ate fine foods that they themselves had asked for.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.4: “How can the Sakyan ascetics eat fine foods that they themselves have asked for?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.5: Who doesn’t like nice food? Who doesn’t prefer tasty food?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.6: The monks heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.7: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.8: “How can the monks from the group of six do this?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.9: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.12: “… Foolish men, how can you do this?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.13: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.14: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.15.1: ‘If a monk asks for any of these kinds of fine foods for himself—that is, ghee, butter, oil, honey, syrup, fish, meat, milk, and curd—and then eats it, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:1.16: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.1: At one time a number of monks were sick.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.2: The monks who were looking after them asked,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.3: “We hope you’re bearing up; we hope you’re getting better?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.4: “Previously we ate fine foods that we ourselves had asked for, and then we were comfortable.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.5: But now that the Buddha has prohibited this, we don’t ask because we’re afraid of wrongdoing. And because of that we’re not comfortable.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.7: Soon afterwards he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.8: “Monks, I allow a sick monk to eat fine foods that he himself has asked for.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.9: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:2.10.1: ‘If a monk who is not sick asks for any of these kinds of fine foods for himself—that is, ghee, butter, oil, honey, syrup, fish, meat, milk, and curd—and then eats it, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.3: ghee from cows, ghee from goats, ghee from buffaloes, or ghee from whatever animal whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.7: sesame oil, mustard-seed oil, honey-tree oil, castor oil, oil from fat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.13: what lives in water is what is meant.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.15: the meat of those animals whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.17: milk from cows, milk from goats, milk from buffaloes, or milk from whatever animal whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.23: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.24: Any of these kinds of fine foods:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.27: who is comfortable without fine foods.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.29: who is not comfortable without fine foods.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.30: If he is not sick and he asks for himself, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.31: When he receives it with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.1.32: For every mouthful, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.1: If he is not sick, and he does not perceive himself as sick, and he eats fine foods that he himself has asked for, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.2: If he is not sick, but he is unsure of it, and he eats fine foods that he himself has asked for, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.3: If he is not sick, but he perceives himself as sick, and he eats fine foods that he himself has asked for, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.4: If he is sick, but he does not perceive himself as sick, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.5: If he is sick, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.2.6: If he is sick, and he perceives himself as sick, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.3: if he asked for it when he was sick, but eats it when he is no longer sick;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.4: if he eats the leftovers from one who is sick;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.6: if it is from those who have given an invitation;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.7: if it is for the benefit of someone else;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.8: if it is by means of his own property;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.10: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc39:3.3.11: The ninth rule, the training rule on fine foods, is finished.
